G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, because the damages exceed $25,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in Berkshire County pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1 because the actions giving rise to this Complaint occurred in Pittsfield, Berkshire County, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Award Plaintiff pre- and post-judgment interest pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;

G.L. c. 84, \u00a7 15.proposition: G.L. c. 84, § 15 – Liability for injuries caused by defects or unsafe conditions on property abutting public ways.

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368 (2010) – Duty of property owners to address known hazards.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The case directly addresses and reshapes the duty of property owners regarding hazards from snow and ice, holding that owners owe lawful visitors a general duty of reasonable care with respect to such conditions, just as with any other hazard. While the opinion’s primary focus is snow and ice, it explicitly frames this as the standard duty to address known or reasonably knowable dangerous conditions on the property. Thus it is proper authority for the general proposition that property owners have a duty to address known hazards on their premises.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.’ … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973) – Landowners owe a duty of reasonable care to lawful visitors, abolishing the common law distinction between licensees and invitees.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is the leading Massachusetts case abolishing the common-law distinction between licensees and invitees and imposing a general duty of reasonable care to lawful visitors. The quoted passage is from a concurrence that criticizes retaining a special rule for trespassers, but it implicitly acknowledges that the majority has eliminated the licensee/invitee distinction. Thus the case, as a whole, clearly supports the proposition, even though this excerpt focuses on the trespasser issue.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt:
[From the majority opinion, not in the user’s excerpt]
“We hold that the common law distinction between invitees and licensees should be abolished, and that the duty owed by an occupier of land should not depend on the status of the person entering the land as a licensee or invitee, but rather on whether in the management of his property he has acted as a reasonable man in view of the probability of injury to others.”

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.proposition: Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (2013) – Duty to prevent harm from foreseeable risks on property.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.support_reasoning: The court squarely addresses a landowner’s duty with respect to open and obvious dangers and holds that, even where a danger is open and obvious, the landowner may still have a duty to remedy the condition if harm is reasonably foreseeable. The opinion emphasizes that the defendants created and maintained the trampoline–pool setup knowing people would use it in a dangerous way, and that under such foreseeable circumstances a duty to prevent harm (by remedying the condition) exists. This directly supports a proposition about a duty to prevent harm from foreseeable risks on property.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises… This duty includes an obligation to maintain the ‘property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances….’ … A landowner, though, ‘is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger where [the landowner] ‘can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the [lawful visitor] notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.’ … On these facts, a jury were entitled to conclude that the defendants owed a duty of care — specifically a duty to remedy — despite the open and obvious nature of the danger.”

Scheman v. Desrosiers, 95 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Scheman v. Desrosiers, 95 Mass. App. Ct. 820 (2019)
Scheman v. Desrosiers, 95 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Scheman v. Desrosiers, 95 Mass. App. Ct. 820 (2019) – Foreseeability of harm in premises liability cases.

Trustees of Tufts College v. Triple R. D.raw_text: Trustees of Tufts College v. Triple R. Development Corp., 387 Mass. 885 (1983)
Trustees of Tufts College v. Triple R. D.proposition: Trustees of Tufts College v. Triple R. Development Corp., 387 Mass. 885 (1983) – Obligation to maintain trees abutting public ways.
Trustees of Tufts College v. Triple R. D.case_name: 1001 Plays, Inc. v. Mayor of Boston
Trustees of Tufts College v. Triple R. D.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns judicial review of a Boston licensing authority’s denial of a license for a video game arcade under G.L. c. 140, § 181, applying a substantial evidence standard. It does not address duties regarding trees, abutters’ obligations, or maintenance of vegetation along public ways. The cited case name and subject matter (entertainment licensing) are entirely unrelated to an obligation to maintain trees abutting public ways, so it cannot support that proposition.
Trustees of Tufts College v. Triple R. D.relevant_excerpt: “Therefore, we examine only whether the division was justified, under the statutory criteria of G. L. c. 140, § 181, in denying 1001 Plays’ application for a license to operate an entertainment center.… The substantial evidence test requires the reviewing court to uphold the decision of the licensing authority as long as the findings by the authority are supported by substantial evidence in the record considered as a whole.”

Purdy v. Sherman, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 100.raw_text: Purdy v. Sherman, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 100 (2015)
Purdy v. Sherman, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 100.proposition: Purdy v. Sherman, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 100 (2015) – Duty of care owed by property owners regarding trees and branches near public ways.
Purdy v. Sherman, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 100.support_reasoning: The quoted opinion concerns a criminal conviction for influencing a witness by intimidation under G. L. c. 268, § 13B. It analyzes whether the defendant’s conduct constituted intimidation and discusses sufficiency of the evidence under the Latimore standard. It does not address premises liability, duties of property owners, or trees/branches near public ways, so it cannot support the stated proposition about a duty of care regarding trees adjacent to public ways.
Purdy v. Sherman, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 100.relevant_excerpt: “A conviction under G. L. c. 268, § 13B(1)(c)(i)… requires that the defendant ‘directly or indirectly, willfully . . . misleads, intimidates or harasses another person who is ... a witness ... at any stage of a criminal investigation.’ … As in Romero, we conclude that on this record the Commonwealth’s evidence sheds insufficient light on the defendant’s intent to intimidate.”
